bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 25, 1900

div1.p: Reed is concerned about his wife's health, but teases her. He discusses work at Keewaydin, and comments on their son's class rank.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 25, 1900
div1.p:
Your
sweet letter of the 20th
came yesterday noon -- and
made me so happy to know
that my darling oomsey
was able to sit up a
little bit, and to still enjoy
her afternoon nap! When
I got to where you said
“I must now take my nap”,
I said to myself, “the Gout
is subsiding, or hasn't been
severe enough to interfere
with that afternoon nap”!
When I hear that you no
longer take any satisfaction
in that afternoon nap, then
I shall begin to feel uneasy!
Another most excellent and fav-
orable sign of your speedy
recovery, lovie, dear, grows
out of the following expres-
sion, “I would also like very
much to have a nice little
toddy”! Ho! Ho! He! He! Ha! Ha!
The old thirst beginning to
return? Well! that is most
interesting! I don't know
just why, but this morning
while still lying on my
little bed, this went through
my head; “Pretty Miss Gout,
was getting too stout,
so she fell on her snout.
And couldn't go out”!
now what do you think
of that, sweet jogygie? Wasn't
that a very pretty rhyme to be
running through your old
Mr Man's head at that hour
of the morning? Plague
take that old hot weather
that was making my pret-
ty Farmer-lady feel so
very uncomfortable! We
thought that you were
having a blizzard up
north -- we can't complain
of the temperature here just
now, as it goes to 86° or
thereabouts every afternoon,
falling to about 70° at night.
It is warm here, especially
from 10 a.m. to 3 P.M -- after
that hour it begins to get cooler,
and the nights are all that
one can desire, even to the
use of a blanket drawn
well up under the chin-
I don't know anything about
why Mr Darboy Reed doesn't
stand any higher in his class,
but I would be willing to
bet that it was due to the
number of points he made
on his examination, and to no
other fact- I suppose that he
barely passed on several
of his subjects- As he passed
and has his commission, he
shouldn't worry about
a little thing like that.
The girls will love him
just as hard as if he
passed at the head of his
class! Of course, you like
Dr Nash - everybody does -
He says those pleasant things
about me, because, like a
sensible man, he knows
that it will please you, and
so, like a good doctor, he
puts you in a more agree-
able frame of mind- See,
lovie, dear? You are a very
sweet oomsey & your mantee
would like very much to
assist Dr Nash in treating
that precious lame “footsey”!
I enjoyed Johnnie Moore's
letter very much- I'll bet
that those Black & Son straw-
berry plants are not worth
a continental! Do I hear you
say, “I told you so”? Well, that's
very true, my sweet joy, but
let's wait and see how much
fruit they have and how
good it is- Perhaps this war-
mer weather will enable them
to take root- I am so glad
that our trees arrived during
a favorable spell of weather.
That was quite lucky -- and
if the winter is not a very
severe one, they ought to do
well and come out beautifully
in the spring- I think that his
last bill was reasonable
enough, as indeed I think of all
his bills are. He had worked
more days on the other than
I had supposed- That made
it alright- That fence will
be a beauty when it is fin-
ished, and will improve the
looks of our darling little
home very much- I so often
think of that sweet little home
and of the pleasant days we
have spent there amongst
the trees and stones. I intend
writing to Mr Moore very
soon. I think that he would
appreciate a letter from
me. How is my sweet baby
daughter getting along with
her studies? Did she get that
letter with the dollar
in it, that her father sent
for being so smart at her
books? She is a precious
sweet child, and Papa is so
glad that mother got her
that silk petty coat. Does
Elizabeth pass Friday night
with her occasionally? How
is old Mr Doogy Johnson?
Give him a chuck under his
chin for his grand-pa-
Good-night my sweet Joys --
old Mr Mantee is now going
to know in for a gentle snooze.
Monday morning - 26th. I have
only time to say Boo! Boo!
to my sweet girls and to
wish them all kinds of
happiness & health. The
Postman is coming-
Kisses & love for my
precious babies.
